notesStmt.note: The second paragraph of this manuscript appears, with revisions, in the beginning of the penultimate paragraph of the Preface to the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. Edward Grier dates the manuscript as "after 1857," but it was probably written before 1855 (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 1:400). The manuscript is written on the back of a City of Williamsburgh tax form.

body.p: The idea of reconciliation—that what has been done, is consumed—Ever, out of its ashes, let new, sweeter, more amicable fruits ripen.—

The idea that no style of behaviour, or dress, or public institutions, or treatment by bosses of employed people, and nothing in the army or navy, nor in the courts, or police, or tuition, or amusements, can much longer permanently elude the jealous and passionate instinct of American standards.—
